newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkey's Erbakan calls for dialogue with Greece.
newsitem.headline: Turkey's Erbakan calls for dialogue with Greece.

text.p: Turkish Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan on Monday called for dialogue with the new government of Greek Prime Minister Costas Simitis which vowed to protest at a grenade attack against a Greek Orthodox centre in Istanbul.
"We want to solve the problems with Greece peacefully on the table and in a dialogue," Erbakan told journalists before a meeting with Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash.
NATO allies Turkey and Greece have long been at odds over the divided island of Cyprus, sovereignty in the Aegean Sea and minority rights.
Tension again rose on Monday when Islamist urban guerrillas threw a grenade at the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate in Istanbul. No-one was injured in the early morning atack.
"We protest against this action and we will ask for a full investigation in order to shed light on how this incident happened," government spokesman Dimitris Reppas told reporters.
He said the building, the seat of Orthodox Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomeos I should have been better guarded. Bartholomeos is the spiritual leader of 250 million Orthodox Christians.
Turkey and Greece came close to war in January over possession of uninhabited islets in the Aegean in a tense military standoff that was averted through U.S mediation.
"Greece's leadership will see that (dialogue) is the only wise path," Islamist Erbakan said. He did not specifically refer to the grenade attack.
Turkey has welcomed the re-election in late September of socialist Simitis whose conservative rival Miltiades Evert is regarded in Turkey as a hawk.
